subject: Re: [junit] Testing on AWT thread
msgSnippet: ... That s fine for values that are static, or when testing a single component that does not schedule events itself via invokeLater or the hidden system event
messageBody:
2008/8/8 Alex Ruiz <alruiz15@...>:
> But I still think using a mechanism similar to GuiTask
> ('invokeAndWait') is good enough for what we usually
> do in a test involving a GUI, that is reading
> properties from a GUI component to verify that their
> values are correct (like the 'getRowCount' example in
> this thread). I haven't seen anything more complicated
> in a test so far.

That's fine for values that are static, or when testing a single
component that does not schedule events itself via invokeLater or the
hidden system event queue.

However, when writing system tests that control and test the system
through the GUI, you don't know how long it takes for an external
event (e.g. a mouse click, keyboard entry or server-side interaction
over the network) to cause a change in the GUI. So you can't just do
an invokeAndWait to query its state. You have to poll the state of
the GUI to synchronise the activity of the test with that of the GUI
and the system behind it.

You also can't query a value from the GUI and then assume that value
to be what you expect, and use it in asserts, for example, because the
behaviour that causes the expected value to be displayed may not yet
have been performed.

In the GUI testing framework I and some colleagues wrote, a large
fraction of the code (25% or more) was involved in synchronising the
test with the system under test. The no-query constraint affected
every aspect of the API. E.g. the API with which the test controls
and makes assertions about the GUI had to entirely follow a "Tell,
Don't Ask" style.

--Nat

--Nat
